STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
May 31, 2024
Kathleen Nikesch
WELLSPRING LUTHERAN SERVICES KENTWOOD
1715 SUTHERLAND DR,
KENTWOOD, MI, 49508-3306
RE: License#: CB410201260
Dear Kathleen Nikesch:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed
on May 22, 2024. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective
action plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this
letter and must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the
corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager, Samantha Way, at (517) 243-9743.
Sincerely,
Melinda Gubbins, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
701 S. Elmwood, Ste. 11
Traverse City, MI 49684
(231) 342-3721
enclosure

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
RENEWAL INSPECTION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION

Licensee Group Organization: Wellspring Lutheran Services
Licensee Designee: DAVID M GEHM
Chief Administrator: Kathleen Nikesch
Name of Agency: WELLSPRING LUTHERAN SERVICES
KENTWOOD
Agency Address: 1715 SUTHERLAND DR
KENTWOOD, MI 49508-3306
Agency Telephone #: 6162814601
Original Issuance Date: 12/01/1991
Service Types: Certify foster homes for license, Place
children in foster home, Supervise
Independent Living

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except for
the following:
CPA Rule 400.12306 Application request
• (3) An agency shall provide the licensee an
application for renewal of the license and
document the action not less than 60 calendar
days before the expiration date of the license. A
renewal application must be provided to a
licensee, regardless of any pending
recommendation for disciplinary action of the
license.
Two of six foster home files reviewed did not provide the licensee an application
for renewal at least 60 days prior to the expiration of the license.
CPA Rule 400.12324 Reevaluation
• (4) An agency shall document placement
specifications consistent with the information
contained in the reevaluation. The placement
specifications must include all the following:
• (a) The age, number, SOGIE, race, ethnic
background, and characteristics of
children preferred by the applicants.

Three of six foster home files reviewed did not document placement specification
related to SOGIE as required.
CPA Rule 400.12327 Special evaluation
• (5) Within 15 days of the conclusion of the
evaluation, an agency shall complete a written
report.
Three of three special investigations reviewed did not have a report completed
within 15 days of the conclusion of the evaluation.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
6/1/2023 INTERIM, CAP approved 6/25/2023
CPA Rule 400.12327 Special evaluation
• (5) Within 15 days of the conclusion of the
evaluation, an agency shall complete a written
report that includes all the following information:
• (c) Dates and places of contacts, names
of persons interviewed, and names of the
interviewers. If children are interviewed,
their last names may not be included in
the report.
One of three special investigations reviewed did not have interviews documented
in the report.
CPA Rule 400.12417 Foster parent information
• (1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with
all the following information before the
placement or replacement of a child:
• (a) Child's name.

Three of eight foster care files reviewed did not have documentation the caregiver
was provided youth's name prior to placement.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
6/1/2023 INTERIM, CAP approved 6/25/2023
6/7/2022 RENEWAL, CAP approved 6/28/2022
CPA Rule 400.12417 Foster parent information
• (1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with
all the following information before the
placement or replacement of a child:
• (b) Child's date of birth.
Three of eight foster care files reviewed did not have documentation the caregiver
was provided youth's date of birth prior to placement.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
6/1/2023 INTERIM, CAP approved 6/25/2023
6/7/2022 RENEWAL, CAP approved 6/28/2022
CPA Rule 400.12417 Foster parent information
• (1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with
all the following information before the
placement or replacement of a child:
• (c) Available known information about the
child's health.
Three of eight foster care files reviewed did not have documentation the caregiver
was provided youth's known health information.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
6/1/2023 INTERIM, CAP approved 6/25/2023
6/7/2022 RENEWAL, CAP approved 6/28/2022

CPA Rule 400.12417 Foster parent information
• (1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with
all the following information before the
placement or replacement of a child:
• (d) Any known history of abuse or neglect
of the child.
Three of eight foster care files reviewed did not have documentation the caregiver
was provided youth's known abuse/neglect history.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
6/1/2023 INTERIM, CAP approved 6/25/2023
6/7/2022 RENEWAL, CAP approved 6/28/2022
CPA Rule 400.12417 Foster parent information
• (1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with
all the following information before the
placement or replacement of a child:
• (e) All known emotional and
psychological factors relating to the care
of the child.
Three of eight foster care files reviewed did not have documentation the caregiver
was provided youth's known emotional and psychological factors.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
6/1/2023 INTERIM, CAP approved 6/25/2023
6/7/2022 RENEWAL, CAP approved 6/28/2022
CPA Rule 400.12417 Foster parent information
• (1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with
all the following information before the
placement or replacement of a child:
• (f) All known behaviors of the child.

Three of eight foster care files reviewed did not have documentation the caregiver
was provided youth's known behaviors.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
6/1/2023 INTERIM, CAP approved 6/25/2023
6/7/2022 RENEWAL, CAP approved 6/28/2022
CPA Rule 400.12417 Foster parent information
• (1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with
all the following information before the
placement or replacement of a child:
• (g) Circumstances necessitating
placement or replacement of the child.
Three of eight foster care files reviewed did not have documentation the caregiver
was provided circumstances necessitating placement.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
6/1/2023 INTERIM, CAP approved 6/25/2023
6/7/2022 RENEWAL, CAP approved 6/28/2022
CPA Rule 400.12417 Foster parent information
• (1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with
all the following information before the
placement or replacement of a child:
• (h) Any other known information to enable
the foster parent to provide a stable, safe,
and healthy environment for the foster
child and the foster family, including
information about siblings who do not
reside in the foster home as provided in
federal law.
Three of eight foster care files reviewed did not have documentation the caregiver
was provided any known information to enable foster parent to provide a safe,
stable, and healthy environment for the foster child and the foster family including
any sibling information.

REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
6/1/2023 INTERIM, CAP approved 6/25/2023
6/7/2022 RENEWAL, CAP approved 6/28/2022
CPA Rule 400.12417 Foster parent information
• (1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with
all the following information before the
placement or replacement of a child:
• (i) Name of assigned social service
worker.
Three of eight foster care files reviewed did not have documentation the caregiver
was provided name of the assigned caseworker prior to placement.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
6/1/2023 INTERIM, CAP approved 6/25/2023
6/7/2022 RENEWAL, CAP approved 6/28/2022
CPA Rule 400.12417 Foster parent information
• (1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with
all the following information before the
placement or replacement of a child:
• (j) Authorization to provide routine and
emergency medical care.
Three of eight foster care files reviewed did not have documentation the caregiver
was provided medical authorization.
CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans
• (2) An agency shall complete written service
plans for each child and parent or parents, as
follows:

• (b) Within 120 calendar days after the
initial removal and at least once every 90
calendar days thereafter.
Two of eight foster care files reviewed, and two of three independent living files
reviewed had service plans submitted outside of the required timeframe.
CPA Rule 400.12502 Program statement
• (2) An agency shall give a copy of the program
statement to a youth before placement in
independent living.
One of three independent living files reviewed did not have documentation the
youth was provided a copy of the program statement prior to placement in
independent living.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
6/1/2023 INTERIM, CAP approved 6/25/2023
CPA Rule 400.12503 Policy and procedures
• (3) An agency shall provide a youth in
independent living with a copy of the agency's
policies and procedures required by this rule.
One of three independent living files reviewed did not have documentation the
youth was provided a copy of the agency's policies and procedures.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
6/1/2023 INTERIM, CAP approved 6/25/2023
CPA Rule 400.12510 Independent living agreement
• (2) The agreement must be signed and dated by
the youth and the social service worker. The
agreement must be reviewed with the youth at
least once every 90 calendar days and a copy
provided to the youth.

One of three independent living files reviewed did not have documentation the
independent living contract was updated and provided to youth quarterly as
required.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
6/1/2023 INTERIM, CAP approved 6/25/2023
FOM 722-06B Family Team Meeting
FTM’s must occur within the required time frames as
outline in the following tables:
Case Plan Development/Reassessment
Initial Case Plan (ISP) – within 30 calendar days before
the case plan due date.
Updated Case Plan (USP) – within 30 calendar days
before the case plan due date.
Permanent Ward Service Plan (PWSP) – within 30
calendar days before the case plan due date.
Placement Preservation/Disruption
At least three business days prior to a planned change
of placement or no later than three business days after
an unplanned change.
Planned and unplanned placement changes include
reunification, placement in a residential setting,
stepdown from a residential or hospital setting, return
from AWOLP, or request for chang in foster
home/relative placements.
Three of eight foster care files reviewed and one of three independently living files
reviewed did not have FTM's completed as required.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
6/1/2023 INTERIM, CAP approved 6/25/2023
6/7/2022 RENEWAL, CAP approved 6/28/2022

FOM 722-06B FTM Documentation
The DHS-1105, FTM Report, must be completed for
every FTM.
The caseworker must enter the FTM information in
MISACWIS using the FTM hyperlink within seven
business days of the FTM.
Five of eight foster care files reviewed and three of three independent living files
reviewed contained FTM's without the DHS 1105 or the DHS 1105 was not
uploaded within seven business days.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
6/1/2023 INTERIM, CAP approved 6/25/2023
6/7/2022 RENEWAL, CAP approved 6/28/2022
FOM 722-08 Supervisor approval
After the caseworker routes the service plan to the
supervisor for review and approval, the supervisor must
approve all case service plans within 14 days of the
end of the report period.
Two of eight foster care files reviewed did not have supervisory approval of the
case service plan within 14 days as required.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
6/1/2023 INTERIM, CAP approved 6/25/2023
6/7/2022 RENEWAL, CAP approved 6/28/2022
FOM 722-08D Treatment Plans
When completed, obtain all signatures as appropriate,
including those of parent(s)/guardian(s), foster care
worker, supervisor, foster parent, caregiver, any youth
aged 14 and older and in the case of placement
agency foster care cases, the local DHS office
designee.
Six of eight foster care files reviewed, and three of three independent living files
reviewed did not contain all of the required signatures on the parent agency
treatment plan (PATP).

REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
6/1/2023 INTERIM, CAP approved 6/25/2023
6/7/2022 RENEWAL, CAP approved 6/28/2022
FOM 801-03 Medical passports
For children entering foster care, the initial medical
passport must be provided within two weeks of the
child’s placement date to the following:
• Foster care provider
• Youth adult voluntary foster care (YAVFC)
youth/young adult re-entering foster care.
The actual date the medical passport is provided must
be documented in the electronic case management
record.
All medical information within the medical passport
must be current and updated at least quarterly to reflect
the child’s current and complete health information.
An updated medical passport is provided to:
• Participating legal parents if the child is
temporary court ward. Quarterly, while in out-of-
home placement. At reunification. Subsequent
medical passports are not required after
reunification.
• Non-offending parent, subsequent medical
passports are not required after reunification.
• The child’s foster care provider at or prior to
each placement.
• All medical and mental health professionals to
whom the child is newly referred to and
accepted for treatment or services prior to or at
the first schedule appointment while the foster
care case is open, regardless of placement.
Subsequent medical passports are not required.
Older youth/young adults:
• Upon initial independent living placement (youth
aged 16 and over).
• Upon exiting the foster care system (youth
adults aged 18 and older).
• YAVFC youth/young adult.

One of eight foster care files reviewed, and one of three independent living files
reviewed did not have medical passports and required signatures.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
6/1/2023 INTERIM, CAP approved 6/25/2023
6/7/2022 RENEWAL, CAP approved 6/28/2022
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• DHS 901 forms must be uploaded within 7 business days of the semi-annual
meeting. This is in line with the requirements for DHS 1105 forms.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
• If a contact did not occur or a meeting did not take place the case documentation
should not state, contact was successful or occurred even if there is additional
narrative that explains the events.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.

There was 1 incident of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period. Special evaluation 2023C0000619 was initiated on 5/22/2023 regarding
allegations a licensed foster parent was utilizing corporal punishment as discipline.
The licensed foster parent was found to be in violation of licensing rules and agency
policy. A CAP was put in place and was successfully completed on 7/28/2023.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 2 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows. The
agency interim inspection was completed on 6/1/2023 and the CAP was approved
on 6/25/2023. The agency was cited for 14 violations, 10 of which were repeated
this year. Of those 10, there was an improvement in individual incident of non-
compliance within 3 (medical passports, DHS 1105's, FTM's) of the violation areas
and an increase in the number of individual incidents in 3 areas (special
investigation report within 15 days of investigation conclusion, placement outlines,
PATP signatures). 4 areas stayed the same from last year's audit (supervisor
approval, IL program statement, IL policies/procedures and IL contract). In 2022, 9
violations were established, 5 of which were repeated this year. All of the repeated
violations remain close to the name number of individual incidents of non-
compliances except for PATP signatures which had an increase for the current
audit. The agency will need to establish additional corrective planning for the
repeated violations to ensure a reduction of incidents.
Special investigation 2024C0001080SI was completed on 1/26/2024 and the CAP
was approved on 2/29/2024. The agency was found in non-compliance as the
agency opened a satellite office prior to obtaining DCWL approval. The agency's
CAP included updating a pre-existing checklist for office moves to include
obtaining DCWL approval prior to making such a move. The agency has complied
with the CAP action steps and no further concerns have been noted.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator Assessment was reviewed. The chief administrator
indicated the agency has had some difficulties due to staff turnover. In addition,
the assessment reports the agency dealt with a relatively high number of
placement changes (77). As a result of the previous year CAP the agency held
multiple policy and rule fresher training sessions. They have also created and
utilized new tracking tools they feel have been useful in all areas but notably
licensing.
Financial Overview
There are no financial concerns identified based on the review of the facility’s
budget and the agency’s financial audit.

Staff Interviews
Interviews were conducted with three staff via telephone. Staff reported feeling
supported by the agency. Supervisor and coworkers are available to assist as
needed. Staff did not report any concerns.
Description of Agency Walk Through
The agency maintains suffice office space, equipment and supplies to ensure
delivery of foster care and licensing services. All files were stored securely and
there is a cross shredder for CHRI.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
There were no identified safety concerns.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency will be issued a renewal of their regular license.
______5/22/2024___________________________
Melinda Gubbins Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
5/31/2024
_____________________________________
Samantha Way Date
Area Manager
